translated: Birth Stories
The Group of Sixes
The Chapter on the Unworthy
The Birth Story of Setaketu

original: “Mā tāta kujjhi na hi sādhu kodho,
analyzed: mā tāta kujjhi na hi sādhu kodhaḥ
translated: “Don’t be angry, my son, for anger is not good.

original: Bahumpi te adiṭṭhamassutañca;🔽Mātā pitā disatā setaketu,
analyzed: te a diṭṭha massutañca  mātā pitā
translated: You have not seen or heard much.
Mother and father are the eastern direction, the banner of the white parasol.🔽The teacher is said to be the most revered direction.
The one who gives food, drink, and clothes to the householder
is also said to be the direction of the mother-in-law.
This direction is supreme, the banner of the white parasol,
having gone to which, the suffering become happy.”
“Those with rough garments, matted hair, and dirty teeth,

analyzed: dummakkha rūpāḥ ye ime jappanti mante
translated: of ugly appearance, muttering mantras—
Are they, by human effort,
freed from the lower realms, knowing this?”
“Having done evil deeds, king,

analyzed: bahu sutaḥ ce na careyya dhamma
translated: if one who is learned does not practice the Dhamma,

analyzed: sahassa vedaḥ api na tam paṭicca
translated: even one who knows a thousand scriptures, because of that,
one is not freed from suffering without practice.”

analyzed: sahassa vedaḥ api na tam paṭicca
translated: “Even one who knows a thousand scriptures, because of that,
one is not freed from suffering without practice.
I think the Vedas are fruitless,

analyzed: sa sa yamam caraṇam eva sat ca
translated: only practice with restraint is true.”

analyzed: na ha iva vedāḥ aphalāḥ bhavanti
translated: “The Vedas are not fruitless,

analyzed: sa sa yamam caraṇam eva sat ca
translated: The life of self-control is true,
For by it one may win great fame,
And by it one may win the peace that comes from self-control.”
The Birth Story of Setaketu, the Second.
